reviews.author: hidden blade
reviews.title: do not take this course!!! you are just wasting your time here
reviews.comment_content:
This course is just about basic English learning. It consists of the following parts:
1. tell you how to become an effective learner.
2. teach you how to deliver a speech in the university and how to do group discussion
3. teach you how to write an academic essay
After I learned all these things, of course, I attended class every time, I found that I did not learn anything really useful for me. Our instructor pointed out our problems, but he did not really tell us how to solve them to improve our English level.
reviews.comment_teaching: To be honest, I just want to say that this course it's not very interesting. Our instructor let us discuss the questions he asked. And that's almost all the content of this boring course. Except these, he just read the sildes. And he also stressed that the grade was not an important thing.
reviews.comment_grading: Really unfair grading system. I just wanted to say that your performance is unrelated to the final grade. Now let me tell a funny story of this ridiculous grading process. I got the final grade first. But the grade for each assignments were not given. So where the final grade came from? I don't know. Maybe the final grade was given by god. I sent an e-mail to my instructor to ask him to offer us the grade for each part. And it was really 'fortunate' that the most important part(writing an academic essay, which weighs most in the grading part) was given the lowest grade, and other parts were given the highest grade. So you know what I mean? I suspected that the grade was given disorderly, I even suspected that he did not truly see our assignments. And I asked lots of classmates in our class, I did not even find one's grade was in b range. We attended every time and submitted every assignment on time. We do them really carefully and prepare lots of for it. At last, we were all given C even D. The CLE system doesn't compare you with your classmates but with other students taught by other teachers. So some students in other class who not submitted their homework on time and do even not take attendance every time got a B or even an A letter at last. That's all about this unfair course. Your effort is really meaningless, a good instructor matters more.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is really huge, you need to search lots of information on the website even if you know that your work is meaningless. It not only  can not help you truly improve your  English level, but also wastes lots of your precious time.

reviews.comment_grading:
Bad grade!
Unfair grading system!
It is a grade killer!
Every teacher has their own criteria to judge your grades of assignments and record your grades in the CLE system. After the whole semester, I guess your final grade is decided by the recorded results updated by each teacher.
I have put effort into the course and finished every assignment carefully. However, I only get exponential in reflective tasks which don't matter in the whole grade. In other assignments, my scores are almost competent, (writing task is advanced/competent), but my last grade is C+, besides, I can't see any grade above B among my classmates, that's quite unfair. In my opinion, the CLE doesn't care whether your scores are good or bad in the class, it just uses the results given by teachers to æ‹‰curve.
The CLE system doesn't compare you with your classmates but with other students taught by other teachers. That results in the situation that one doesn't work hard but his/her teacher encourages him/her and gives a grade like advanced/exponential when he/she makes improvements during the semester. However, some unlucky students may be taught by a strict teacher, and the teacher seldom gives good grades like 'advanced' in assignments which accounts for a high proportion of grades.
Even he works hard, he wouldn't get a good grades he expected. At last, the class is not worth working hard for. If you have a strict teacher, the CLE system will give you an unfair grade eventually.
reviews.comment_workload:
The class is not worth working hard for!
Before class, you are required to do something. There are 5 assignments to be updated during the whole semester. Each will cost you a lot of time if you want to grade a good in the class. 2 electives are also required to be done. But, at last, it doesn't matter whether you do your homework, because the grades are mostly decided by the assignments. The CLE is an idiot, unfair and stupid system. If your 5 assignments get good scores, others won't influence your grade, (or maybe you will get a subgrade). I'm very angry since all my efforts only contribute to a C+. All mistakes are caused by the stupid system!

Course Description

In this course, you will explore the theme of the future and what kinds of ideas, technologies, issues or challenges that might be important for the world in 30-50 years. You will practice and develop your English language learning proficiency especially in Speaking (academic discussions and short speeches) and Writing (paragraphs and short essays). You will also work on your academic literacy skills that help with your work and studies at university level. These include how to use and integrate sources in your speaking and writing assignments, how to interact and contribute to academic discussions. In addition to language learning and academic literacy, you will develop self-directed learning strategies where you will complete a combination of out of class online tasks, choose online electives relevant to your learning needs, and reflect on your learning both individually and from peer and teacher feedback.



Course Theme â€“ The Future

Humankind has imagined, thought about, prepared for and predicted the future for many years and for many reasons. Humans do this on many levels: as individuals, as groups, as communities, societies and nations. Our ability to estimate and speculate what might happen in the future is perhaps very significant now in the age of information and scientific/technological progress. This has led humankind to be more aware of global issues and challenges such as climate change and even more importantly, the science and technology that can be used to solve problems and improve the world. In this course you will explore the theme of the future and choose a topic of your interest to complete the assessed speaking and writing tasks. The topics should be related to any future science, technology, business trends Links to an external site., or global issues/challenges that will be important to the world in the next 30-50 years.

A) OVERVIEW OF 3 UNITS
Unit 1: we will cover skills for self-directed learning and how to be an effective language learner. These include evaluating learning goals, practices and habits, exploring learning strategies and online resources to help you develop your own skills. You will also cover written language skills that will help you with the Academic Writing Task 1 - Writing a paragraph on the future. These skills will help you to be a responsible learner to succeed in your university life. The Core Areas for learning covered here are: i) Being an effective learner (EL), ii) Written Language (WL) and iii) Spoken Language (SL).

Unit 2: we will develop speaking skills. In particular, we focus on interaction skills and spoken language that can be used in academic discussions. These skills will help you with the Academic Speaking Task 1: Discussion Skills Assessment at the end of the unit. The Core Areas for learning covered here are: i) Interaction (IN) and ii) Spoken Language (SL).

Unit 3: we will develop writing skills to help you with Academic Speaking Task 2 (Short speech) and Academic Writing Task 2 (Short essay) - Summarising Different Perspectives Assessment.  We focus on developing skills for producing coherent, accurate and well supported writing that you can apply in writing short academic essays. We will also cover skills that will help you in planning and preparing engaging short speeches. The Core Areas for learning covered here are: i) Written Language (WL) , ii) Substance (SU)  and iii) Coherence (CO)



B) OVERVIEW OF SELF DIRECTED LEARNING (SDL)

Self directed learning (SDL) is study that you do in your own time outside regular class time. SDL is intended to develop your competencies that will help you:

1) Develop your academic discussion skills

2) Develop your effective learning and reflection skills

3) Develop your academic speaking and writing language skills

reviews.author: Pluto12138
reviews.title: Nice Instructor & Fair Grading
reviews.comment_content:
Fundamentals for university English learning. Topics include:
Unit 1: Course introduction, methodology for English learning, paragraph development, language style.
Unit 2: Discussion under an academic context. Listening, participating, and speaking skills.
Unit 3: Coherence and substance in speaking and writing. Developing perspectives, summarising, and paraphrasing. Skills for short speeches.

Students need to finish 2 out of 4 electives. Topics include vocabulary accumulation, paragraph development, confidence for speaking. Most of them are easy quizzes or videos. A few may require you to meet an iLANG advisor at the language centre.

There are some SDLs (Self-directed learning), including discussing with classmates and uploading the video, summarising perspectives for your chosen topic (about future, which you will use throughout the course), etc. Some of them may appear to be a little bit trivial and time-consuming at first, but many turn out to be very useful for the graded assessments.

But I have to say the content of this class is sometimes too general and methodological. Many of the class discussions are boring because Year 1 students are forced to discuss the significance of many theories and notions. Many of the examples for discussions are obstruse and not so illustrative. Maybe they can introduce things more implicitly and include more practical examples.
reviews.comment_teaching: Fiona is an approachable and easy-going instructor. Although she said she is not known as a lenient figure in her first class and frightened us a little bit, she is actually kind and patient. If you have problem with things like grading and so on, it is OK to discuss with her directly. She is willing to help students after class and she always includes her experiences in the discussion, which makes the classes more engaging.
reviews.comment_grading:
There are no exams in this course, so the grading is completely based on assignments and class performances. The grading scheme may differ from class to class, but it basically includes:
1. 6 assessment: a) Academic Writing Task 1 - Paragraph on the Future - 5% of course grade (Week 6); b) Academic Speaking Task 1 - Discussion Skills Assessment - 25% of course grade (Week 7), c) Academic Writing Task 2 - Summarising Different Perspectives -Short Essay - 30% of course grade (End of semester), d) Academic Speaking Task 2 - Summarising Different Perspectives -Short Speech - 20% of course grade (End of semester); e) Reflective Task 1 - Talking head video submission - 5% of course grade (Week 9); f) Reflective Task 2 - Written submission - 5% of course grade (End of semester).
You can and are suggested to use your chosen topic about future for all these assignments. It reduces your pressure for researching and give you more freedom for the content. The first speaking assessment is in a f2f mode. There is a monologue and a group discussion. The second speaking and first reflective task ask you to submit a video.
2. Self-directed learning (SDL) - 10% of course grade (Throughout semester). Electives included. These are only graded for participation, so people should get full mark if they participate and hand in things on time.
3. Attendance. Its is said that attendance counts for some grades in other classes. In our class, it is taken but does not contribute to grading.  

Assignments are graded into five levels. Getting exceptional and advanced in most assignments should ensure people an A range grade. Most students in the class have moderate English abilities and are not like fluent, imposing native speakers. So, time devotion, expansive research and careful editing should help to get better grades.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is not too big, considering all the assessments are scattered to the entire semester and people can work on the same topic. Starting early is highly recommended, as you donâ€™t want to work on the assignments during your precious final weeks. It also gives people more time for editing and proof reading.
